channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Deadly explosion in central Ankara
item.description: A car bomb has exploded in the Kizilay district in the Turkish capital Ankara, with officials saying at least 27 people are dead.

item.title: Militants kill beach-goers in Ivory Coast
item.description: At least 14 civilians and two soldiers are shot dead at a beach resort in Ivory Coast, in an attack claimed by al-Qaeda-linked militants.

item.title: Parents of drowned twins 'devastated'
item.description: The parents of twin boys who drowned in a fish pond at their Fife family home speak about the loss of their "miracle babies".

item.title: England win Six Nations as France lose
item.description: England win their first Six Nations title since 2011 as France's defeat by Scotland gives Eddie Jones' men an unassailable lead.

item.title: Osborne warns of cuts of 50p per £100
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne says there will be further cuts to public spending in his Budget, equivalent to 50p in every £100.

item.title: Teen anorexia 'sign of narcissism'
item.description: The rise of eating disorders such as anorexia among teenagers is a sign of narcissism in society, broadcaster Baroness Joan Bakewell has said.

item.title: Merkel suffers regional election setbacks
item.description: The party of German Chancellor Angela Merkel suffers defeats in two of three states holding regional elections, exit polls suggest.

item.title: Palestinian wins global teaching prize
item.description: A Palestinian teacher who grew up in a refugee camp has been named as the most exceptional teacher in the world.

item.title: Pilot confidentiality 'must be relaxed'
item.description: French investigators call for medical confidentiality to be relaxed for pilots, in their final report on last year's Germanwings air crash.

item.title: Actress Beacham 'reveals rape trauma'
item.description: Actress Stephanie Beacham, whose roles include TV series Dynasty and Tenko, tells a newspaper about being raped during the early 1970s.

item.title: Police payout for murdered boy's parents
item.description: The parents of a 14-year-old boy murdered by a man he met online receive a police payout and an apology over how the case was handled.

item.title: Arsenal 1-2 Watford
item.description: Watford stun FA Cup holders Arsenal at the Emirates Stadium to book their place in the semi-finals at Wembley.

item.title: VIDEO: Turkish capital hit by huge explosion
item.description: A suspected car bomb has hit the Turkish capital, Ankara, with reports of at least 27 dead and dozens more wounded.

item.title: VIDEO: Several killed in Ivory Coast beach attack
item.description: Police in Ivory Coast say several people have been killed in an attack on the popular tourist resort of Grand Bassam.

item.title: VIDEO: Ceausescu's palace: Inside former dictator's home
item.description: The home of Romania's former communist ruling couple, Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu, has been opened to the public 27 years after they were executed.

item.title: VIDEO: How a cat changed an autistic girl's life
item.description: Arabella Carter-Johnson explains how her autistic daughter's life was transformed by Thula the cat.

item.title: VIDEO: Would you take a dose of hookworms?
item.description: Scientists are infecting healthy volunteers with hookworms to help the development of a vaccine against the parasite.

item.title: VIDEO: Lebanon's rivers of rotting rubbish
item.description: Protests prompt the government in Lebanon is to temporarily reopen a landfill site to end the rubbish crisis in Beirut.

item.title: VIDEO: Obama warns against 'insults and taunts'
item.description: US President Barack Obama has warned White House contenders to avoid raising tensions, a day after a rally by Donald Trump was called off amid clashes.

item.title: VIDEO: 20 years since Dunblane shootings
item.description: It is 20 years since 16 students and their teacher were killed at Dunblane Primary School in Scotland.

item.title: Little impact from online abuse summit
item.description: At South by Southwest Interactive, an inaugural summit is trying to tackle issues around online harassment.

item.title: Dutch to hold stormy referendum on EU-Ukraine deal
item.description: The Netherlands is to hold a controversial referendum in April on the EU's new partnership with Ukraine, Anna Holligan reports.

item.title: What does 'Islam' think of America?
item.description: US Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump says Islam hates America, but is there anything to back up his claim?

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn and the EU referendum
item.description: Labour is campaigning for the UK to remain in the EU, but how enthusiastic is leader Jeremy Corbyn about the UK's relationship with Brussels?

item.title: Aston Villa 0-2 Tottenham Hotspur
item.description: Tottenham close the gap on leaders Leicester to two points after Harry Kane's quickfire double sinks struggling Aston Villa.

item.title: Manchester United 1-1 West Ham United
item.description: Anthony Martial's late equaliser means Manchester United and West Ham will replay for place in the FA Cup semi-finals.

item.title: Hibernian 1-2 Ross County
item.description: Alex Schalk scores an 90th-minute winner as Ross County beat Hibernian to win the Scottish League Cup final.

item.title: Scotland 29-18 France
item.description: Scotland earn a first victory over France for 10 years that also confirms England as Six Nations champions.

item.title: Doubts over EDF's Hinkley nuclear plan
item.description: Fresh doubts arise over French energy firm EDF's plans for an £18bn nuclear power plant at Hinkley Point in Somerset.

item.title: Slow China output fuels recovery fears
item.description: Chinese industrial production slows to its weakest growth since the financial crisis, as Britain warns China's slowdown could derail the global recovery.

item.title: Turkey EU membership 'not on the cards'
item.description: Turkey joining the EU is not "on the cards any time soon", George Osborne says, adding that the UK has "a veto" on the issue.

item.title: Calm down over leadership, Watson warns
item.description: Labour's deputy leader calls for politicians across his party to "calm down", amid speculation about a possible leadership challenge.

item.title: Doctors urge more social care funding
item.description: Doctors' leaders write to George Osborne asking for further funding for social care in next week's Budget.

item.title: Disabled people face benefits change
item.description: More than half a million disabled people could lose out as a result of further changes over the next four years to welfare payments.

item.title: Education is 'toughest reform' - Blair
item.description: Changing the education system is "one of the most difficult things" for a government, said former UK prime minister Tony Blair.

item.title: School chief bans use of 'Trojan Horse'
item.description: Birmingham's education commissioner says he has banned the use of the term "Trojan horse" to describe the allegations of attempts to take over schools in the city.

item.title: Human scores first win over AlphaGo
item.description: Go master Lee Se-dol wins a game against Google's AlphaGo program, after losing three in a row in a best-of-five competition

item.title: Click: Watch a full show in 360 degrees
item.description: Technology show Click makes history with the BBC's first interactive fully 360-degree programme.

item.title: Mars mission targets Monday launch
item.description: All looks good for an on-time launch on Monday of the joint European and Russian ExoMars mission, which will try to track down the Red Planet's sources of methane.

item.title: Europe's rarest seabird 'faces extinction'
item.description: The Balearic sheerwater will be extinct within 60 years, according to a new analysis.

item.title: Eagles of Death Metal singer's apology
item.description: Eagles of Death Metal singer Jesse Hughes apologises for suggesting some Bataclan security guards may have had advance warning about the venue being attacked in Paris last year.

item.title: Progressive rock legend Emerson dies
item.description: Progressive rock legend Keith Emerson of Emerson, Lake and Palmer dies of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, aged 71, police tell the BBC.

item.title: Why don't they make shoes for black ballet dancers?
item.description: Black ballet dancer Eric Underwood has had to paint his own shoes. Does ballet have a colour problem?

item.title: Why Chinese officials are afraid to look too smart
item.description: Why Chinese officials don't want to be seen in expensive shops

item.title: Your pictures: Flags
item.description: Readers' photographs on the theme of flags.

item.title: Week in pictures
item.description: A selection of the best news photographs from around the world taken over the past week.

item.title: Justice for all?
item.description: What should governments do to bring fair representation to all?

item.title: When does borrowing from other cultures become wrong?
item.description: Why we should borrow from other cultures

item.title: The children who just want to go home
item.description: They want to go home despite the bombs

item.title: The 1980s cars being targeted by thieves
item.description: The alarming rise in 1980s car thefts

item.title: The mothers who set up a radiation lab
item.description: The Japanese mothers who set up a radiation lab

item.title: Is fermented food a recipe for good gut health?
item.description: What's good for the gut about pickled cabbage?

item.title: VIDEO: Armpit hair, a depressed elephant... and other trends of the week
item.description: Plus baby DiCaprio and other trends of the week

item.title: Weekend Edition: The week's best reads
item.description: The girl groomed online and kidnapped at 13, plus other reads

item.title: Go Figure: The week in numbers
item.description: The week's big numbers visualised
